nschultz.watcher.core

Class DirectoryWatcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • nschultz.watcher.core.DirectoryWatcher
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class DirectoryWatcher
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    The {@link DirectoryWatcher} is used to watch a directory for changes. These changes could either be that a file has been created, deleted or modified.
    To use this class simply create an instance of it, specify the directory that you wish to watch and pass a {@link DirectoryWatchable} instance you wish to notify about those changes. After the initializing of this class you can use the startWatching method to start and the stopWatching method to stop the {@link DirectoryWatcher} again. If the stopWatching method is not invoked the {@link DirectoryWatcher} will keep watching the specified directory.
    Note that this watcher does not look inside directories in the specified folder for changes. That means only the root directory will get watched for changes.
    Since:
    0.1.0
    Version:
    0.1.0
    Author:
    Niklas Schultz

    • Constructor Detail

      • DirectoryWatcher

        public DirectoryWatcher(@NotNull
                        java.nio.file.Path dirToWatch,
                        @NotNull
                        DirectoryWatchable dirWatchable)
        Creates a new instance of {@link DirectoryWatcher}.
        Parameters:
        dirToWatch - the directory that will be watched for changes
        dirWatchable - the DirectoryWatchable instance that want't to get notified about changes on the specified directory
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given path points to a file that is not a directory

    • Method Detail

      • startWatching

        public void startWatching()
        Starts watching the specified directory for changes. In case the {@link DirectoryWatcher} has already been started this call will have no effect.
        Note that this method can also be used to restart the {@link DirectoryWatcher} after the stopWatching method was used to stop the watcher.

      • stopWatching

        public void stopWatching()
        Stops watching the specified directory for changes. In case the {@link DirectoryWatcher} has already been stopped this call will have no effect.
        Note that the old thread that did the watching will be destroyed if it was running after this call returns.

      • run

        public void run()
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
